quotes.quote: You don't get anything clean without getting something else dirty.
Housework, if you do it right, will kill you.
My second favorite household chore is ironing. My first being hitting my head on the top bunk bed until I faint.
No matter how many house chores you complete, there are always more to be done.
Man is made for something better than disturbing dirt.
It is amazing how quickly the kids learn the operation of the DVD, yet are unable to understand the vacuum cleaner.
Housework's the hardest work in the world. That's why men won't do it.
Everybody wants to save the earth; no one wants to help mom do the dishes.
Housework won't kill you, but then again, why take the chance?
There is no need to do any housework at all. After the first four years the dirt doesn't get any worse.
You don't get anything clean without getting something else dirty.
Dirt is only matter in the wrong place.
A spotless house is a sign of a misspent life.
The cruel irony of housework: people only notice when you don't do it.
Housework is work directly opposed to the possibility of human self-actualization
A clean house is the sign of a boring person.
Dusting is a good example of the futility of trying to put things right. As soon as you dust, the fact of your next dusting has already been established.
Housework is the only activity at which men are allowed to be consistently inept because they are thought to be so competent at everything else.
Invisible, repetitive, exhausting, unproductive, uncreative â€“ these are the adjectives which most perfectly capture the nature of housework.
The trouble with living alone is that it's always your turn to do the dishes.
Cleaning your house while your kids are still growing is like shoveling the walk before it stops snowing.

If your house is really a mess and a stranger comes to the door greet him with, 'Who could have done this? We have no enemies!

When all else fails, cleaning house is the perfect antidote to most of life's ills.
Dust is a provocative coating for fine furniture.
Housekeeping is like being caught in a revolving door.
We labor to make a house a home, then every time we're expecting visitors, we rush to turn it back into a house.
More important than a clean house is a close family.
We are used to cleaning the outside house, but the most important house to clean is yourself - your own house -
Now, as always, the most automated appliance in a household is the mother.
The labor of women in the house, certainly, enables men to produce more wealth than they otherwise could; and in this way women are economic factors in society. But so are horses.
We dream of having a clean house - but whose dreams of actually doing the cleaning?
